close_symbols: definition of fd_set (system header / FD_* macros)
explanation:
To determine whether MHD_select violates the MISRA C rule that pointers should point to const-qualified types whenever possible, the next analyzer needs the declarations and implementations that establish whether pointers passed or used in MHD_select must be mutable or could/should be const. For each symbol:

- struct MHD_Daemon (full definition): MHD_select takes a struct MHD_Daemon *daemon and dereferences many fields (shutdown, options, itc, listen_fd, was_quiesced, connections, connection_limit, at_limit). You must know which fields are modified by MHD_select or by callees to decide if daemon could be a pointer-to-const or whether non-const is required.

- resume_suspended_connections (prototype + implementation): MHD_select passes daemon to this routine. You must know whether that callee modifies the daemon or requires a non-const pointer; if it does not modify daemon, its parameter (and the call site) might be a candidate for const qualification.

- internal_get_fdset2 (prototype + implementation): Called with &rs, &ws, &es, &maxsock. You must know whether it writes to these arguments (clearly it probably does) to decide if their pointer types could be const. Also check signature for maxsock parameter constness.

- MHD_add_to_fd_set_ (prototype + implementation): Called with fd and pointers to fd_set and maxsock; you must know which pointer parameters are modified so you can judge whether they could be const.

- MHD_itc_r_fd_ (prototype + implementation): Returns an FD used in add-to-fdset call; if it takes an itc pointer you must know if that parameter is const-qualified.

- MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (macro/function): Used on daemon->itc; you need its signature/definition to know if it treats the itc pointer as const or non-const (affects whether daemon->itc could be const).

- MHD_get_timeout64 (prototype + implementation): Called as MHD_get_timeout64(daemon, &mhd_tmo). You must know whether it modifies daemon or only reads it, and whether its second parameter is an output (non-const) or could be const. That affects whether daemon could be const and whether &mhd_tmo should be non-const.

- internal_run_from_select (prototype + implementation): Passed &rs, &ws, &es; you must know whether that function mutates the fd_set arguments. If it only reads them it could (and should) take const fd_set* parameters; if it mutates them it must be non-const. That directly impacts whether pointers in MHD_select should be const.

- MHD_SYS_select_ (prototype): Wrapper around select — signature determines whether the timeval and fd_set parameters are declared const or non-const. POSIX select typically takes non-const pointers because it may modify fd_sets and timeval; you must inspect the wrapper signature to confirm whether tv or fd_set parameters are declared const (which affects whether tv or other pointers in MHD_select could be const-qualified).

- typedef/definition of MHD_socket and MHD_INVALID_SOCKET: maxsock and ls are of MHD_socket type. You need the typedef to see whether functions taking MHD_socket* expect const or non-const and whether passing &maxsock could be const-qualified.

- definition of fd_set (system header / FD_* macros): To determine whether fd_set objects are intended to be modified by select/callees (and thus require non-const pointers) you need the concrete semantics (select modifies fd_set in-place), and to confirm how the project uses them.

- definition of struct timeval (system header): timeval may be modified by select on some systems; you need the precise wrapper signature (MHD_SYS_select_) and the timeval type to decide whether tv could be const.

- MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ (macro definition): This macro is used multiple times and may accept daemon pointer; its definition tells whether it treats daemon as read-only (could be const) or modifies/accesses fields that require non-const.

In short: any callee prototypes and type definitions that establish whether the pointer targets are read-only or written are required. The above list is the minimal set of declarations/implementations needed to decide whether pointer parameters and local pointers in MHD_select can/should be const-qualified without changing behaviour.
